lesson.name: Lesson 8.4: Solving Quadratic Equations with the Zero Product Property

page.title: 8.4.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn about the zero product property. You will use it to reason about the solutions to quadratic equations that each have a quadratic expression in factored form on one side and 0 on the other side.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain the meaning of the "zero product property."
  • Find solutions to quadratic equations when one side is a product of factors and the other side is zero.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 8.4.1: Introducing the Zero Product Property
  • 8.4.2: Solving Equations of Increasing Complexity Using Reasoning
    • 8.4.2: Self Check
    • 8.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.4.3: Applying the Zero Product Property to Solve a Real-World Projectile Problem
    • 8.4.3: Self Check
    • 8.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.4.4: Solving Equations Using the Zero Product Property and Reasoning

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 8.4.5: Practice
  • 8.4.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 8.4.1: Introducing the Zero Product Property
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

What values of the variables make each equation true?


  1. \(6+2a=0\)

Enter the value or values of the variables.

Compare your answer:

\(a=-3\)


  1. \(7b=0\)

Enter the value or values of the variables.

Compare your answer:

\(b=0\)


  1. \(7(c−5)=0\)

Enter the value or values of the variables.

Compare your answer:

\(c=5\)


  1. \(g \cdot h=0\)

Enter the value or values of the variables.

Compare your answer:

Either \(g=0\) or \(h=0\), or \(g=h=0\)


  1. What did you notice about one of the factors in each of the previous problems?

Enter what you noticed.

Compare your answer:

At least one of the factors in each equation was 0 or equivalent to 0.


We will use the zero product property to help solve quadratic equations throughout this lesson.


ZERO PRODUCT PROPERTY

If the product of two expressions is 0, then one or both of the expressions equal 0.

If \(ab=0\), then \(a=0\) or \(b=0\), or \(a=b=0\).

page.title: 8.4.2: Solving Equations of Increasing Complexity Using Reasoning
page.contents:
Activity

For each equation, find its solution or solutions. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

For questions 1–3, review the process of solving equations.

  1. \(x−3=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=3\)


  1. \(x+11=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=-11\)


  1. \(2x+11=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=\frac {-11}{2}\)


For questions 4–7, recall the zero product property means that each (or all) of the factors could be equal to zero when their product is zero. Solve each equation by setting each factor equal to zero and solving.

  1. \(x(2x+11)=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=0\) and \(x=\frac {-11}{2}\)


  1. \((x−3)(x+11)=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=3\) and \(x=-11\)


  1. \((x−3)(2x+11)=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=3\) and \(x=\frac{-11}{2}\)


  1. \(x(x+3)(3x−4)=0\)

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=0\), \(x=-3\), and \(x= \frac {4}{3}\)


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Use factors of 48 to find as many solutions as you can to the equation \((x−3)(x+5)=48\).

Enter the solution or solutions for the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=7\) and \(x=−9\)


  1. Once you think you have all the solutions, explain why these must be the only solutions.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The numbers expressed by \(x−3\) and \(x+5\) are 8 units apart. The only factor pairs of 48 that are 8 units apart are 4 and 12, as well as –4 and –12.

Think:

  • What value of \(x\) would make the factors \((x−3)(x+5)\) equivalent to \((4)(12)\)? \(x=7\).
  • What value of \(x\) would make the factors \((x−3)(x+5)\) equivalent to \((-4)(-12)\)? \(x=-9\).

Check:

  • If \(x=7\), then \((x−3)(x+5) = 4 \cdot 12\).
  • If \(x=-9\), then \((x−3)(x+5)=-12 \cdot (-4)\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Find the values that make each of the factors equal to 0. While \(x=-4\) is correct, check your solution when solving the factor \((8x−16)=0\). The answer is \(x=2\) and \(x=-4\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The signs on these answers are opposite of the correct responses. Find the values that make each of the factors equal to 0. The answer is \(x=2\) and \(x=-4\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Find the values that make each of the factors equal to 0. While \(x=2\) is correct, the other value is not. Check your solution when solving the factor \((x+4)=0\). The answer is \(x=2\) and \(x=-4\).

That’s correct! Check yourself: Substitute each value into the equation and check if they are true. \((2+4)(8(2)−16)=0\), and \(((-4)+4)(8(-4)−16)=0\). Since they are both true, your answer is correct.

page.title: 8.4.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving Equations of Increasing Complexity Using Reasoning

Let’s look again at the zero product property.


ZERO PRODUCT PROPERTY

If the product of two expressions is 0, then one or both of the expressions equal 0.

If \(ab=0\), then \(a=0\) or \(b=0\), or \(a=b=0\).


We can use the zero product property to help reason through finding the solutions to complex quadratic equations.

We know that if factors are multiplied together and the result is 0, then one of those factors must equal 0.

Example 1

\((x−7)(2x+12)=0\)

This equation has two different factors that, when multiplied, result in a product of 0.

To find possible solutions to this equation, we can set each factor equal to 0 and solve.

\((x-7)=0\;\;\;\;\;\;\;(2x+12)=0\)

The value \(x=7\) makes the first factor equal to 0. The value \(x=−6\) makes the second factor equal to 0.

So, the solutions to the original equation are \(x=7\) and \(x=−6\).

Example 2

\(x(x−9)(3x−8)=0\)

This equation has three different factors, but the reasoning is the same. We can still set each factor equal to 0 and solve.

The first factor is just \(x\). So, \(x=0\) is a solution.

The second factor gives a solution of \(x=9\) when we solve \((x−9)=0\).

The third factor gives a solution of \(x=\frac {8}{3}\) when we solve \((3x−8)=0\).

So, the solutions to \(x(x−9)(3x−8)=0\) are \(x=0\), \(x=\frac {8}{3}\), and \(x=9\).

Try It: Solving Equations of Increasing Complexity Using Reasoning

Use the zero product property to reason through finding the solutions to the following quadratic equations.

  1. \((x−6)(4x+20)=0\)
  1. \((x+1)(5x+14)=0\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Think about which values make each factor equal to 0.

  1. \(x=6\) and \(x=-5\)
  1. \(x=-1\) and \(x=\frac {-14}{5}\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.4.3: Applying the Zero Product Property to Solve a Real-World Projectile Problem
page.contents:
Activity

We have seen quadratic functions modeling the height of a projectile as a function of time.

Here are two ways to define the same function that approximates the height of a projectile in meters, \(t\) seconds after launch:

\(h(t)=-5t^2+27t+18\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;h(t)=(-5t−3)(t−6)\)


  1. Which way of defining the function allows us to use the zero product property to find out when the height of the object is 0 meters (when the object is on the ground)?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The one with a quadratic expression in factored form.


  1. Without graphing, determine at what time(s) the height of the object is 0 meters (when the object is on the ground). Show your reasoning.

Enter the times(s) and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

The object has a height of 0 meters after 6 seconds. Applying the zero product property to solve \((-5t−3)(t−6 )=0\) gives \(t=- \frac {3}{5}\) and \(t=6\). Because the object was launched at \(t=0\), the negative solution doesn’t make sense in this context.


  1. Using the function in quadratic form, determine the height of the object before it started its motion, at \(t=0\) seconds. Explain your reasoning.

Enter the height of the object and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

The object has a height of 18 meters at 0 seconds. By substituting 0 for \(t\) into the quadratic form, the starting height can be determined. \(h(0)=-5(0)^2+27(0)+18=18\).


Video: Applying the Zero Product Property

Watch the following video to learn more about applying the zero product property to solve a real-world projectile problem.

page.title: 8.4.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The equivalent functions below model the height of a projectile in meters, \(t\) seconds after launch.

\(h(t)=-8t^2+27t+20\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;h(t)=(-8t−5)(t−4)\)

Without graphing, determine at what time the height of the object is 0 meters (when the object is on the ground).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The projectile does not start on the ground. Set the function in factored form equal to zero and solve. There are two solutions, \(t=− \frac {5}{8}\) and \(t=4\). In this context of time, the solution must be positive. You would not have a negative amount of time. The answer is 4 seconds.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Set the function in factored form equal to zero and solve. There are two solutions, \(t=− \frac {5}{8}\) and \(t=4\). In this context of time, the solution must be positive. You would not have a negative amount of time. The answer is 4 seconds.

That’s correct! Check yourself: There are two solutions to the function when it is set equal to 0. Since \(t=− \frac {5}{8}\) is negative, it does not make sense in this context of time. You would not have a negative amount of time. The answer is 4 seconds.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Set the function in factored form equal to zero and solve. There are two solutions, \(t=− \frac {5}{8}\) and \(t=4\). In this context of time, the solution must be positive. You would not have a negative amount of time. The answer is 4 seconds.

page.title: 8.4.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Applying the Zero Product Property to Solve a Real-World Projectile Problem

We have previously looked at functions representing the motion of projectiles. We analyzed two equivalent expressions that define the same quadratic function, one in quadratic form and the other in factored form.

Now we’re going to look at a similar problem, but with the additional knowledge of how the function relates to the zero product property.

Let’s look at an example.

The equivalent functions below model the height, in feet, of a baseball \(t\) seconds after being hit.

\(h(t)=−15t^2+44t+3\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;h(t)=(−15t−1)(t−3)\)

Using the zero product property, the quadratic expression in factored form allows you to more easily find out when the height of the baseball is 0 feet.

Without graphing, we can determine at what time the baseball reaches the ground.

Let’s apply the zero product property to solve \((−15t−1)(t−3)=0\).

Set each factor equal to 0 and solve.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}-15t-1&=&0\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;t-3&=&0\\-15t-1\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}1} &=&0\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}1} \;\;\;\;\;\;\;t-3 \; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}3} &=&0\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}3} \\-15t&=&1\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;t&=&3\\\frac{-15t}{-15}&=&\frac1{-15}\\t&=&-\frac1{15}\end{array}\)

So, \(t = - \frac {1}{15}\) and \(t = 3\). These values of \(t\) represent the roots of the function. Because the object was launched at \(t = 0\), the negative solution doesn’t make sense in this context of time. So the baseball reaches the ground in 3 seconds.

There is one benefit of knowing the function in quadratic form. By substituting 0 in for \(t\), we can easily determine at what height the baseball was hit, when \(t = 0\) seconds.

\(h(t)=−15t^2+44t+3\)

\(h(0)=−15(0)^2+44(0)+3\)

\(h(0)=3\)

So, the baseball was hit at a height of 3 feet. Note that this point, \((0, 3)\), is the \(y\)-intercept of the function when graphed.

Try It: Applying the Zero Product Property to Solve a Real-World Projectile Problem

The functions below model the height of a projectile in feet, \(t\) seconds after launch.

\(h(t)=-24t^2+94t+63\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;h(t)=(-12t−7)(2t−9)\)

  1. Without graphing, determine at what time the height of the object is 0 feet.
  1. Determine the height of the object before it is launched.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve this projectile problem using the zero product property:

  1. \((-12t−7)(2t−9)=0\)

\(t=-\frac {7}{12}\) or \(t=4.5\)

The object has a height of 0 feet at 4.5 seconds.

  1. \(h(0)=-24(0)^2+94(0)+63=63\)

The object starts at a height of 63 feet.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.4.4: Solving Equations Using the Zero Product Property and Reasoning
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Find all solutions to \((x+5)(2x−3)=0\). Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter the solutions to the equation and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

\(x=-5\) and \(x=\frac {3}{2}\)

By the zero product property, either \(x+5=0\) or \(2x−3=0\), so \(x=-5\) and \(x=\frac {3}{2}\).

page.title: 8.4.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–4, solve each equation. Identify every correct answer.

  1. \(x(3x+12)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x = 0\) and \(x=-4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x−7)(x+9)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=7\) and \(x=-9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x−8)(4x+15)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x=8\) and \(x=- \frac {15}{4}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x(x−6)(5x−20)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=0\), \(x=4\), and \(x=6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5 and 6, use the following.

The functions below model the height of a projectile in feet, \(t\) seconds after launch.

\(h(t) = -7t^2 + 34t + 48\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;h(t) = (-7t − 8)(t − 6)\)

  1. Without graphing, determine at what time the height of the object is 0 feet.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 6 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Determine the height of the object before it is launched.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.4.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 48 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 7–10, solve each equation. Identify every correct answer.

  1. \(x(6x−18)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.4.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x=0\) and \(x=3\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x+13)(x−9)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=-13\) and \(x=9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x−7)(x−7)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.4.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x=7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x− \frac {5}{6})(6x+30)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x = -5\) and \(x=56\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 8.4.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the meaning of the "zero product property."
  • Find solutions to quadratic equations when one side is a product of factors and the other side is zero.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 8.4.1: Introducing the Zero Product Property
    • In this activity, you learned how the zero product property affects factors being multiplied together in an equation set equal to 0.
  • 8.4.2: Solving Equations of Increasing Complexity Using Reasoning
    • In this activity, you implemented the zero product property to solve increasingly complex quadratic equations.
    • 8.4.2: Self Check
    • 8.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.4.3: Applying the Zero Product Property to Solve a Real-World Projectile Problem
    • In this activity, you applied the zero product property to solve a real-world problem involving projectiles. You increased your knowledge of these types of problems that you have seen in previous lessons.
    • 8.4.3: Self Check
    • 8.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.4.4: Solving Equations Using the Zero Product Property and Reasoning
    • In this activity, you demonstrated all of the skills you learned in this lesson to continue solving challenging quadratic equations.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 8.4.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
